EXECUTIVE SUMMARY OF RMP
MEMC Electronic Materials, Inc.
Saint Peters, MO


40 CFR 68.155(a)
Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies

The plant approach to chemical safety is summarized in the Corporate Environmental, Safety, 
and Health Policy.  ?MEMC Electronic Materials will strive to achieve an injury-free and healthful 
workplace for our employees, and work toward minimizing effects on the surrounding 
environment, and ensure the safety of our community neighbors, contractors and visitors.?
 
MEMC 
+? is certified to the ISO14001 international environmental standard
+? has systems in place to protect employees, community, and environment
?+ has emphasized accident prevention at the site since its beginning in 1959
?+ is a member of the St. Charles County Local Emergency Planning Committee
?+ has its own trained Emergency Response Team with members onsite 24 hours a day
?+ coordinates its ERT with Central County Fire and Rescue to provide rapid response to any 
sort of incident

Central County Fire and Rescue
+? is designated to respond to any incident that requires more capability than MEMC?s first 
responders can provide
?+ provides or recommends training for MEMC?s ERT members
?+ has a station is about two miles from the plant entrance
?+ can have its first units arrive on site in less than five minutes


40 CFR 68.155(b)
The Stationary Source and Regulated Substances Handled

The plant is regulated as an Intermediate Source of air emissions with Facility ID 183-0027, and 
holds an Intermediate Operating Permit, OP2006-077.  The site is among the largest silicon wafer 
manufacturing plants in the world, located on 200 acres and employing 900 people.

The process consists of melting pure silicon into single crystals, then slicing these into wafers, 
planarizing them to perfect flatness, and polishing them to a perfect finish in a cleanroom 
environment.  Some wafers receive an additional coating, in the form of an epitaxial layer that 
gi

ves them certain electrical characteristics, as specified by customers.

Three gases used in this EPI process account for the storage of three chemicals that are 
managed under OSHA?s Process Safety Management program.  These PSM-regulated gases are 
hydrogen, hydrogen chloride, and trichlorosilane.  These are the same three substances 
regulated under EPA?s Risk Management Plan as well.


40 CFR 68.155?
General Accident Release Prevention and Chemical-Specific Prevention Steps

MEMC accidental release prevention is based on the Process Safety Management standard.  
The three regulated RMP chemicals identified above are managed under PSM.  Elements of the 
PSM program include evergreen and actively maintained written operating procedures that are 
followed by trained and knowledgeable technicians.

Over time, MEMC has built a detailed collection of process safety procedures to insure 
standardized chemical handling and usage. The procedures begin with a safety section to 
reinforce the main theme of "Safety First".  Management Of Change is formally controlled in 
covered processes to ensure no unauthorized changes occur.  Job Safety Analyses or Risk 
Assessments are also used as applicable, to identify hazards and control risks.  These are step-
by-step reviews of tasks to ensure these jobs are done according to the safety standard.

Prevention steps include:
?+ Tank and vessel inspection program to check mechanical integrity
?+ Safety relief valve test program to ensure equipment functions as designed
?+ Process Line Entry Permit for servicing piping and equipment and returning it to service
?+ Hot Work Permits, Fire Prevention Plans, and related procedures
?+ Sprinkler systems and firewalls to minimize the threat of fire or explosion

MEMC measures the Serious Incident Rate for the plant each month, to include all accidents 
and incidents and potential incidents, not simply injuries.  Those classified Serious Incidents are 
thoroughly investigated according to a s

et procedure, and tracked in formal Corrective Action 
Request system.  Safety suggestions and safety work order programs provide all employees with 
the opportunity to participate in finding and reporting barriers to safety.

MEMC uses a formal Chemical Registration process that will not allow any new chemical 
substance in the plant unless it has received proper review for safe use, storage, and eventual 
disposal.  Chemical usage is tracked by month, by chemical, by department.


40 CFR 68.155(d)
Five-Year Accident History

Within five years of the date of this revision, there have been no releases of any regulated 
substance held above the threshold quantity from a covered process.

So there is no information available about deaths, injuries, property damages, environmental 
damages, evacuations, or sheltering in place, because none of these occurred in the five-year 
period.

Also, none have occurred during the 47 years the facility has been in operation.


40 CFR 68.155(e)
Emergency Response Program 

All employees are trained to dial the Plant Emergency Hotline from any plant telephone in case of 
a chemical release, fire, or medical emergency of any kind.  That emergency number is also 
posted on all plant telephones.  The Hotline and the plant's emergency alarms go to the security 
desk in the main lobby.  The security officers activate the site Emergency Response Team paging 
system and will summon other plant resources, including Central County Fire and Rescue when 
needed.

The response is handled by the plant's Emergency Response Team, and Central County Fire and 
Rescue when necessary.  MEMC ERT members are 40-hour HazWoper trained and given 
refresher training annually.  Emergency Medical Responder training has also been provided. 
Periodically, MEMC?s ERT and Central County Fire and Rescue review emergency responses 
and plans, and conduct joint training exercises.
 
In the event of an emergency with off-site consequences, MEMC would work with Centra

l County 
Fire and Rescue.  CCFR would adhere to the National Incident Command System, summon and 
coordinate any other necessary resources including medical response, law enforcement, and 
hazmat teams from a multi-county area, and determine whether to evacuate off-site locations, 
shelter in place, or implement other actions.


40 CFR 68.155(f)
Planned Changes to Improve Safety

In addition to the maintaining the prevention program elements described above, MEMC may 
conduct the following activities to further improve safety at the site:

+? Additional safety and emergency response training
?+ Periodic replacement of older equipment; and
?+ Continued improvement of the PSM program elements
